Notes: Schools are back to in person learning   https://archive.ph/lTZiy

For Iftar tents for Ramadan, local committees and NCEMA teams in each emirate are being authorised to approve the setup of these tents, define the numbers of participants for each one, and determine their locations in coordination with the ERC.   There is mandatory application of the Green Pass system according to the rules in place by each emirate. Iftar tent organisers or personnel are to provide masks and sterilisation tools and to direct people to adhere to all precautionary and preventive measures, including mask-wearing, physical distancing, and constant hand sterilisation.  Using disposable table covers is mandatory, according to the protocol which also recommended disposable plates, cups and spoons for each individual while ensuring people sit one meter apart on dining tables.  https://archive.ph/ln6bE

For Iftar tents for Ramadan, local committees and NCEMA teams in each emirate are being authorised to approve the setup of these tents, define the numbers of participants for each one (TBC), and determine their locations in coordination with the ERC.   There is mandatory application of the Green Pass system according to the rules in place by each emirate. Iftar tent organisers or personnel are to provide masks and sterilisation tools and to direct people to adhere to all precautionary and preventive measures, including mask-wearing, physical distancing, and constant hand sterilisation.  Using disposable table covers is mandatory, according to the protocol which also recommended disposable plates, cups and spoons for each individual while ensuring people sit one meter apart on dining tables.  https://archive.ph/ln6bE

Is a curfew in place? No  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Abu Dhabi requires people to show their testing and vaccination status using the Al Hosn app   to enter public venues, including parks, beaches, malls, hotels, gyms, cafÃ©s, restaurants, and large supermarkets. The Al Hosn app also facilitates contact tracing to reduce the spread of the virus.  https://archive.ph/MwIoV

(Continued)  - All unvaccinated arrivals aged 12 years and above, must quarantine for 10 days.     -All vaccination certificates issued from GCC countries, or issued by countries which Bahrain has signed a mutual vaccination recognition agreement, or issued by countries whose citizens are eligible for a visa on arrival will be accepted upon entry, or containing a QR code for vaccines approved by the World Health Organization, or the Kingdom of Bahrain, will be accepted upon entry will be accepted.    - Fully vaccinated: completed 14 days after the second dose in a two-dose vaccination series (e.g. Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca, etc.) or completed 14 days after administration of a single dose for single-dose vaccination series (e.g. Johnson & Johnson).    - All passengers and airline staff are screened at all entry points of the airport and at travel gates.  - All travelers arriving in the Kingdom of Bahrain aged 6 years and above are required to:  1. Present a verified PCR test certificate bearing a QR code, administered no more than 72 hours before boarding the inbound flight.   2. Take a PCR test upon arrival.  3. Recently recovered passengers (age 6 years and above) are not required to present a negative PCR test before departure. In lieu of a negative PCR test, passengers who have recently recovered from a COVID-19 infection can present documentary proof in the form of a recovery certificate or a positive PCR test taken no later than 14 days prior to departure and no earlier than 30 days prior to departure. Passengers are still required to undergo a PCR test on arrival in Bahrain.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220318125710/https://www.bahrainairport.bh/covid-19-travel-information

In lieu of a negative PCR test, passengers who have recently recovered from a COVID-19 infection can present documentary proof in the form of a recovery certificate or a positive PCR test taken no later than 14 days prior to departure and no earlier than 30 days prior to departure. Passengers are still required to undergo a PCR test on arrival in Bahrain.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220318125710/https://www.bahrainairport.bh/covid-19-travel-information

Travellers entering the country must show a negative negative COVID-19 PCR test 72 hours prior entering the country; and will be tested up arrival.  "All passengers over the age of 11 leaving or entering Djibouti, including those who have been vaccinated, must show a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours of boarding any flight bound for Djibouti and not more than 120 hours prior to their arrival at Ambouli International Airport (JIB). All travelers entering the country will also be tested for COVID-19 upon arrival and must wait at the port of entry until the results become available."    https://web.archive.org/web/20220216120454/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/01/djibouti-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-domestic-and-international-travel-restrictions-as-of-jan-17-update-23

The Government of Djibouti offers COVID-19 tests at King Fahd and has a pop-up site near the Treasury. While the test itself is free, a negative COVID-19 test certificate costs 5,000 Fdj or $30. Additionally, you may pay 5,000 Fdj to request a test be conducted at your residence. Test results are delivered by phone.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220101162250/https://covid19.gouv.dj/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220101161354/https://dj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220101161426/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/557591/djibouti-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-domestic-and-international-travel-restrictions-as-of-dec-17-update-2

Djibouti currently has supplies of AstraZeneca, Sinovac, and Sputnik V and Johnson & Johnson. Individuals ages 18 and above are currently eligible to be vaccinated.
